Name: Linear Programming
Description: A problem where the objective function and constraints are all linear.  It's the most common and well-studied type.  Solved using the Simplex method or other linear methods.
Example: A company wants to maximize profit based on production levels of multiple products
Appearances: subject to constraints on resources like labor and materials.

Name: Integer Programming
Description: A variant of Linear Programming where some or all variables must be integers.  More complex than LP.
Example: A scheduling problem where the number of workers assigned to each task must be a whole number.

Name: Nonlinear Programming
Description: A problem where the objective function or constraints (or both) are nonlinear.  Solution methods can be more complex.
Example: Maximizing a yield function in chemical engineering
Appearances: where the yield is a nonlinear function of temperature and pressure.

Name: Dynamic Programming
Description: A technique for solving optimization problems by breaking them down into smaller
Solvability: overlapping subproblems and storing the solutions to these subproblems to avoid recomputation. Usually used for sequential decision making.
Appearances: Finding the optimal route for a delivery truck considering travel times at different times of day.

Name: Stochastic Programming
Description: A type of optimization problem that deals with uncertainty in the parameters of the problem (e.g.
Example: costs).  Solutions often involve scenarios and probabilities.
column8: A manufacturer trying to decide how much to produce

Name: Robust Optimization
Description: A technique for optimization problems where the parameters are uncertain
Solvability: but the optimization is performed to satisfy certain performance guarantees
Example: regardless of the specific parameter values.
column8: Designing a bridge that can withstand a range of environmental conditions.

Name: Convex Optimization
Description: A problem where the objective function and feasible region are convex. This guarantees that any local optimum is also a global optimum.

Name: Quadratic Programming
Description: A problem where the objective function is quadratic and the constraints are linear.
Example: Portfolio optimization where the investor wants to maximize return subject to a budget and risk constraints.

Name: Knapsack Problem
Description: A classic problem where you have a set of items
Solvability: each with a weight and a value
Example: and you want to select a subset of items to maximize the total value while staying within a weight capacity.
column8: Packing items into a backpack to maximize the total value without exceeding the weight limit.

Name: Portfolio Optimization
Description: A type of problem where the objective is to find the optimal mix of assets that maximize returns while minimizing risk
Appearances: Determining the best asset allocation for a stock portfolio
